characters: CAMERA CONTINUES MOVEMENT IN SAME DIRECTION
CAMERA FOLLOWS THEM DOWNWARD TO REVEAL
CAMERA TRACKS IN ON HIS FACE

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Snow flakes falling against a black sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like a warm cozy place out of "It's A Wonderful  Life". The window is flocked with fake snow, and hung wit colorful Christmas lights, wreaths and ornaments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barman, wiping down the counter, gives an occasional  semi-furtive glance toward the far end of the bar. Other patrons chat near the bartender and also give occas glances toward the far end of the bar. It is early evenin happy hour -- and the clientele is well-heeled and sociab A customer says something interrogative to the bartender, who looks down the bar and shrugs. REVERSE - CAMERA CONTINUES MOVEMENT (Notes the combinatio of the HIGH ANGLE and the tilt of Santa's head keep his f from being clearly revealed in this scene). Sitting alone at the far end of the bar, given a wide ber by the other customers, a man (WILLIE) stares morosely in his drink. The drink is clearly not his first. He wears a red velvet suit and red velvet hat with a whit pom-pom. He has shiny black boots with red velvet trim. H long white beard is not real and is in fact pulled down b his chin to facilitate drinking. It exposes heavy black  stubble. Swaying slightly, he raises the drink to the vicinity of lips. Once it gets close he must navigate it in with some effortful coordination. He takes a sip and sets the drink carefully back down. After another long, staring, morose beat, he starts weepi It is loud, dolorous, and unself-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santa staggers out the back door... CAMERA FOLLOWS BEHIND HIM still hiding his face. Santa gets about ten feet, then pauses and leans with one hand against the alley wall, uses the other to hold his p pom out of the way, and vomits. Having vomited, and spit, he staggers off toward the stre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An upbeat woman TRAINER presides over a half-dozen SANTAS sitting at school desks. On the blackboard the Trainer is writing out the sixth "Santa Commandment".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1) No alcoholic beverages before or during your shift. 2) Know the names of your reindeer. 3) Do not smoke in your costume. 4) No swearing. 5) Absolutely no flirting. 6) Coax a smile from the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she writes) Coax... a... smile... from... the  child. (turning to face them) Remember, parents don't want photos  where their child isn't smiling.  Some children may not want to smile.  It is your job to coax a smile out  of them. A good line to remember is: "Santa thinks everybody should be  happy. Can you smile for Santa?" A  camera can only copy a child's smile --  it will take you to put it there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she talks we

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND
dialogues.text: one of the Santas (WILLIE). His HAND reaches into a boot pulls out a pint of Smirnoff. We FOLLOW UP IN C.U. to see this hand pour a few ounces into a can of Coke he holds b his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the child will not smile, the  Photo Elf will go ahead and take the  picture anyway. Now, it is a good  Santa's job to smile as well -- I  know with the big white beard your  smile will be partially hidden, so  you must learn to smile with your  eyes. They show warmth and can be  very expressive.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE'S FACE
dialogues.text: as he finishes off the can of Coke to REVEAL: his eyes co than those of a dead fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember you have been chosen for  the starring role of Santa Claus.  Your portrayal of this beloved  character will have a major impact  on every child you meet. Keep in  mind at all times that to them, you  aren't a man dressed up like Santa,  you are Santa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLIE'S FACE. His expression reads: "Please kill me".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wintry night. Ray Coniff's "Jolly Ole Saint Nicholas" sco views of the downtown blanketed in snow and decorated for the holiday. It is Christmas Eve, and the sidewalks thron with people rushing to do their last-minute shopping. A MOTHER and her two absurdly bundled CHILDREN emerge fro the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry boys, we're gonna miss Santa!  She drags them across the street  toward the looming art-deco monolith  that is the big-city department store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother and children crest the escalator to emerge on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The older child is pointing at a prop gate with a candy-c letter sign: TO SANTA'S WORKSHOP. He runs and Mom shoos her younger child to join him. The boys cross the threshold of the gate and their eyes f with wonder. A winding path cuts through a flocked and candy-striped  forest, past a workshop filled with mannequin-elves busil cobbling Christmas toys, and finally arriving at... Santa, seated on his throne like a scarlet Messiah. The  younger child staggers forward to join the line of a hund other leaky-nosed worshippers awaiting an audience. At the head of the line the next waiting child is escorte to Santa's chair by a smiling tiny man (MARCUS) dressed a an elf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An imitation BACK STREET BOYS quintet sings Christmas Car Grown-ups busy themselves draining their wallets as a VOI comes over the intercom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attention shoppers: the store will  be closing in five minutes. We hope  tomorrow is a pleasant Christmas and  thank you for shopping with us, your  friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Purposeful haste eddies the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. PHOTO PRINTING OUT
dialogues.text: The Photo Elf takes the digital photo and presents it to MOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dutifully reciting  his spiel) My, what a darling picture! Are you  certain you only want the single?  Additional photos come in handy as  gifts for grandma and grandpa or a  wonderful remembrance for friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, I'll just take the  single.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her credit card as CAMERA MOVES OVER TO SANTA. O his knee is a YOUNG BOY who whispers excitedly in his ear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disinterested) Uh-huh... yeah... done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Boy climbs off and runs away, A BRATTY KID jumps up Santa's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you in another mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not even looking at  him) Right... Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not really Santa. If you were  Santa you could do magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him) You want magic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santa pushes him off his lap and shoves him on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, I just made you disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santa turns to his Elf,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Elf nods as he peels off a pointed prosthetic ear. Sa pulls a fifth of Old Grandad from the cushions of his thr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Thank fuckin' Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a swig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the sound of closing circuits, banks of lights  systematically shut down in the various departments of th now empty store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs the last of the store employees file out the d past an old SECURITY GUARD. Eventually Santa emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Willie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have it your way, Willie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me which way to have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Security Guard heads for a panel near the doorway and punches a key labeled ARM. An L.E.D. readout labeled "ARM counts down from 30 seconds. The guard exits the store, locks the door and heads home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large Teddy bear sits under a Christmas tree. Suddenly -В— it moves, bolting upright and sprinting from room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alarm continues to count down -- 15... 14... The Teddy bear slides down the space between the railing the escalators. Landing on its feet, it barrels toward th door.
The Teddy bear scrambles for the door, crashing into  everything in its path.
Running past a clothing display, it rips the arm off a  mannequin without breaking stride.
It skids to a stop at the base of the alarm box, too shor to reach the controls.

It raises the mannequin arm, using the pointed finger on hand to press the "CANCEL" key on the keypad. Mission accomplished, the teddy bear rips off its head to reveal his true identity: Santa's Elf -- in civilian life known as MARCUS SKIDMORE. He is covered in sweat and pant like an asthmatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hasp flips open and Marcus swings the door wide to reve a beer-guzzling Santa-in-the-off-season known as WILLIE T SOKE. He finishes the beer, crushes the can and drops it his feet next to eight more empties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus sneers at him as he lumbers past:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and Willie tear open the prop presents on the work set and remove several tools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus reaches into jewelry cases and removes a few parti items. He drops them into a stock cart then checks a type list before moving on. Marcus pushes the cart through the store, gathering an od array of items that range from furs to gowns to shoes to  makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus arrives outside a doorway and looks in to see Will manning a large water drill and putting it to work on the store's vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm finished when I'm finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm goin' downstairs... (referring to list) I need a melon-bailer and a loofah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drill suddenly revs higher, getting Willie's attentio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus moves closer as Willie pulls back the drill on the track. He places a screwdriver into the exposed lock asse and hits it with a sledgehammer. Suddenly, the door swings open and bundled cash spills to the floor. Both men are impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck the loofah, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and Willie wheel out two carts and roll them throu the open doors of a waiting van. As they slam the doors -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie settles on the rear bench as Marcus gets into the  passenger seat next to his Pillipina Mail-order wife of  several years, LOIS, who is dressed in expensively ugly  clothes, and whose mouth is ever down-turned in pruney  distaste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus, did you get the loofah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van speeds away through the Christmas Eve night and  disappears into the distance, like the down of a thistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ROCKETS INTO C.U. of An alarm clock ringing with a jolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie, in bed, blearily wakes to the insistent alarm. He tries to turn it off, but his fingers are still clotted w sleep. In a series of frustrated grunts and groans he becomes mo and more aggravated until, finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCK YOU, YOU FUCKING PIECE OF SHIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bolts out of bed and throws the clock into the wall. He stoops for some beer bottle empties and hurls them at clock debris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you! Fuck you! Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One final scream and it's out of his system. He finds one last bottle in his hand, half-full with a cigarette butt  floating in it. He downs the beer and steps into the adjoining bathroom t brush his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie, sipping a cup of coffee, meanders down the street scratching his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie's walk brings him to a fancy eatery at lunchtime. he passes, he casually snatches a handful of car keys fro the parking valet key-box and moves on. As he rounds the corner into the lot he pushes on the var key fobs, identifying various cars when their alarms chir He seems dissatisfied until a brand new Cadillac chirps. Willie gets in and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Willie drives. He reaches over into the glove compartment and pulls out the registration. He focuses on the car own address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie, eating a corn dog, saunters down an opulent hallw a beer swinging in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In long shot, through the open door of an extravagant mar bathroom, we see Willie sitting on the toilet, leafing th a magazine, beer bottle on the counter next to him. Pants around his ankles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie, standing by the toilet, finishes buckling his bel and flips the flush lever. Nothing happens; no whoosh of rushing water. Willie, looking down into the toilet, gives the lever a c more clanking tries, and then grabs his beer and ambles o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sucking on his beer, Willie paces the periphery of the ro methodically knocking painting after painting off the wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie arrives in the bedroom still knocking down paintin until, finally, he exposes a wall safe. A smile, and he pulls out a stethoscope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The safe door swings open to reveal stacks of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie scratches a lottery ticket. He's now wearing a Rol and some gaudy ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for another one and we see that on the bartop front of him are neat stacks of lottery tickets as yet  unscratched, and an untidy jumble of scratched ones. On the other side of the bar a MIDDLE-AGED STRIPPER vies his attention. Willie's ticket hits for $5.00.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tucks it into the Stripper's G-string, swigs a drink, resumes scratching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie and the Stripper stagger into his apartment, drunk As he passes his blinking answering machine:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got messages. Go wash yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a dancer, I sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you smell like a bum's nutsack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she exits, he activates the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Soke, this is Andrew Kaplan again from the collection agency -- BOOP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie skips to the next message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie, I don't care man, I'm not  looking to blame anyone, but that  diamond isn't a real stone, man. I  took it to -- BOOP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie skips to the next message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, hello, this is Helen Axelrod --  you ran into my car last week? Well  I called State Farm but they have no  record of any insurance policy for  you and -- BOOP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie skips to the next message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie, it's Marcus. It's that time  of year again. Pack your shit.  Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the chimey chords of "Sleigh Ride," we see Phoenix, Ar in MONTAGE / dressed for Christmas but sweltering under i oppressive winter heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the heat ripples rising off the pavement two mira like figures cross the infinite asphalt of the Saguaro Sq Mall parking lot -- Willie and Marcus in Santa and Elf  regalia, sweating and panting in the heat. Willie polishe off a pint of Smirnoff's and flips it towards a nearby tr can. It misses and breaks loudly on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Can you maybe keep it  together for just ten minutes?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls some Tic Tacs out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For crying out loud, chew a few of  these... you drunken, fuckin'  imbecile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anchoring the huge mall complex is the large and upscale  Chamberlain's Department Store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amid the bustle of holiday shopping, an angry heavy-set m with a Grizzly Adams beard stomps away from the pursuing  store manager, Bob Chipeska.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harrison, please I Just let me  explain. Financially, the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get what you pay for, Chipeska!  Five Christmases I've given my heart --  my soul -- my love to these kids,  and now what? Now you flip me for  some stranger who'll do it for peanuts  and happens to work with a real  midget! Lemme tell you something:  nobody cares! Nobody comes here for  the elf, Santa's the attraction! I  do Burl Ives songs; does this schmoe  even play guitar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harrison, it's not the money or the  midget. Believe me, if it was, I --  I don't think they like "midget". I  think you're supposed to call them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, forget it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harrison stomps away and right toward Marcus and Willie a they enter the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hacks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie and Marcus stop in their tracks and watch the burl man storm out. Bob Chipeska watches with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Bob Chipeska. I, please, I, uh --  please don't listen to him. Great  resume and photo by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks... you know, we been at this  a long time an' all, so we like to  think we do a good job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Beautiful Girl wearing skin-tight pants walks by, catch Willie's eye. He stares wantonly at her ass, off in his o little world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two are the best men for the  job. Truly. So do not let his...  unpleasantness affect your performance  in any way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, we're fine, w --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irked, snapping out  of his daydream) Performance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie's reaction worries Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea. Your performance... you know,  the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Performance. Like sexual?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie no, he --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saying there's something wrong  with my gear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Your gear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... fuck stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OKAY! We're gonna head upstairs now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus shoves Willie, who stalks off. Marcus lingers to s things over. He forces a grin and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not gonna say "fuck stick" in  front of the children, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Joke. Adult joke. For  us. Adults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, long, long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another beat. Marcus pantomimes helpless laughter, noisel throwing his head back and holding his gut as it heaves w mirth. He is instantly composed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On an upper floor of Chamberlain's the theme is "The Dese as Winter Wonderland." Cacti and tumbleweeds are wrapped  with lights and flocked with snow, and a team of nine stu burros are hitched to a sleigh. Rudolfo the Red Nosed Bur is tended by several Santa's elf mannequins. One in cowbo wear and another in a poncho and sombrero. Again there is a line of waiting children. Marcus makes h way through the line as kids gasp and cheer. He plays to crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas! Santa's coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yayyyyyy! Marcus gets to the head of the line, ducks unde the velvet rope and goes behind the flimsy cardboard set. Willie sits there morosely, head slumped, forearms on kne red velvet hanging limply from one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck you doing, "fuck stick"  in front of the boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like that guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a bottle from the floor by his feet and swigs of it. Marcus stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like any guy. You think I  can't find another portly motherfuck  can run a water drill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie just slumps there apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tempt my hand. You blow this  and we're broke for the year. So  stop acting like you know something  because, pal of mine, you don't know  squat. You're gum on my shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now put on your fuckin' hat and get  out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the hat, slams it into Willie's chest and, as Wi rises, kicks him in the ass. Willie just takes it, shambl off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And try to act professional. For  Chrissake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the outskirts of the Saguaro Square Mall's parking lot city bus stops with a hiss. The doors swing open to revea pathetic EIGHT-YEAR-OLD KID, overweight, snot-nosed, badl dressed and probably smelling of pee. As the kid nears the mall entrance he passes a group of o children doing skateboard stunts. They notice him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of them throws an empty can that hits him in the head The kid walks on, it seems without noticing. The bullies, disheartened by the lack of reaction, go bac to their skateboarding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus leads a LARGE HEAVYSET BOY over to the throne. The boy eats a chocolate ice cream cone which is smeared all  over his mouth and T-shirt. Marcus lifts him with effort a groan onto Willie's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, wuddya want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nintendo Deer Hunter 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HEAVYSET BOY hops off onto Willie's foot by mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOWWWCH! Watch the toenails willya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus puts a young girl on his lap. She looks up at him awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Wuddya want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Santa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, c'mon, c'mon, wuddya want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Barbie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus puts another young boy on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fraggle-stick car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Fuck is that? (back to the kid) Fine, whatever, next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Next. Next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Next, goddamnit! Let's move it  along -- this is not the DMV!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus walks over to the rope. The snot-nosed Kid is next line, frozen by fear. Marcus pulls on his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid stays put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid shakes his head meekly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You can tell me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How about Santa? If you don't  tell him, you won't get a present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This penetrates the Kid's fear. He moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's right. Let's tell Santa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus leads the Kid up to the throne and places him on  Willie's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want? C'mon, wuddya want?  A snot rag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid just stares, motionless except for the flowing ri of snot. Willie can't help but stare at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) ...Another fuckin' mongoloid. (shouts) Marcus I get him outta here before  he pisses on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the Kid is moved to yank Willie's beard. He hold it stretched below Willie's chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered to the kid) ...Let it go, you little bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was real. The hair fell out when  I got sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved a woman who wasn't clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Santa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, her sister. (whispers through  clenched teeth) Let the fucking thing go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it like at the North Pole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the suburbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thank the fuck Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the elves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, them. They stay with  Mrs. Santa. I get 'em on weekends.  Run me a bath, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the reindeer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading) Don't start with the fucking reindeer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid sits on a stool, hands on his knees, staring,  motionless. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What're their names?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie lies in the tub, also motionless, a wet washcloth  over his face, fingers of one hand resting against a tumb filled with ice and amber liquid that sits on the edge of the tub. From under his washcloth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Oh, fuck... (then, to the Kid) I -- I can't remember... Sneezy, and  Dopey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Seven Dwarves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, is that not...? I just -- fuck,  I don't know, I'll just say, Hey,  Bub -- Look, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drags the washcloth off his face and looks at the kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...FUCK ME! I DON'T KNOW THIS FUCKING  SHIT! WHY IS EVERYTHING A FUCKING  TEST WITH YOU?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid looks at him, unperturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- How old are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie staggers in, a towel around his waist, the empty r glass in one hand, a bottle tucked under the other arm, t Kid trotting after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want cookies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm milk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie carefully, carefully puts glass and bottle down on the nightstand and slowly raises both hands in a "Don't.. Move" gesture to keep them from flying off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I fix you some sandwiches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is with the fixing sandwiches?  No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satisfied that the bottle and glass are not going anywher Willie climbs unsteadily onto the bed and stares at the  ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. You want anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. As soon as the bed stops moving  I'm going to sleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Wake me up... when the little  hand is on the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat. The ragged breath of drunken sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus's wife Lois stands in front of a mirror, trying on cashmere scarf. Her look of pruney disapproval is in plac as ever. She takes off the scarf and writes something in small spiral notebook...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the store, she spies the jewelry counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lois stands looking intently down through the glass case pruney disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help you with anything, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without bothering to look up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he drifts away she takes out her spiral notebook and m more notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie and Marcus nosh on food-court Gyros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck me? Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't just take up with some  kid! You don't know who's around,  what they do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got some nerve you little shit  ya. You my mom now?! You shat me out  your --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that last night you stupid  fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, shit! Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lois appears with a salad on a tray and a look of pruney  disapproval. She sits next to Marcus and, in the way of o couples comfortable with each other, he rests a hand on h knee and continues to talk, ignoring her, while she picks through her salad, ignoring him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are by far the dumbest most  pathetic piece of maggot-eaten shit  that has ever slid from God's gilded  ass! What if the kid has one of those  fucking play-dates they have now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shittin' me?! He doesn't have  fucking friends! Not even an imaginary  one! Unless he got ditched by him!  He's just a fuckin' misfit! Lives  with his grandma who sits drooling  in front of the TV! Every once in a  while she gets up to play soccer  with her tits! What, she's gon' rat  me out? She don't know her ass from  last Tuesday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fuck her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus! Why is everything sex with  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With me? I fuck one person, I ain't  out there serial fornicating, trying  to float my liver! Drinkin' myself  silly 'cause I can't stand what a  piece of shit I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lois, chewing on her salad, notices someone walking by wi a Chamberlain's bag. She glances in as the person passes  and, still chewing, gets out her notebook and jots someth down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you, fuckin' Sigmund Sawed- Off Freud? The shrunken fuckin'  shrink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right, shit-for-brains,  talk about my height. Make it about  something safe. 'Cause you're an  emotional fucking cripple. Your soul  is dog shit. Every single fuckin'  thing about you is ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well... fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and Lois get up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen anal warts more attractive  than you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk off. Willie sits there for a moment. Goes back eating his hamburger. A WOMAN comes up with her TODDLER i tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, look who's here Jimmy! It's Santa!  Let's tell him what you want for  Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting, food flying  out of his mouth) I'M ON MY FUCKING LUNCH BREAK HERE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting her hands  over the Toddler's  ears) Are you insane?!! How dare you talk  like that in front of a child! The  management is going to hear about  this... I'm going to have you fired!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a threat? You think you can  make my life any worse, you go ahead,  be my fucking guest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws his hamburger back down on his tray and storms  off, leaving the woman shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie and the Kid sit opposite each other over a game of checkers. Willie scowls as the Kid thinks for an eternity about his next move. The silence is deafening. Endless. Then... CLICK! CLICK! CLICK! CLICK! CLICK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie stares at the board for a long beat. He leaps up screaming and flings the board across the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCK YOU! YOU FUCKING CHEATER!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie throws checkers one by one against the wall,  punctuating each throw with an insult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a BITCH! ...you LOUSY...  STINKEN... ROTTEN... CHEATING... NO  GOOD...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON Kid's face, unfazed, still smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. The kid lies in bed, sleeping peacefully. Distant sounds of the slosh of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Churning water. The sloshing of water is now accompanied by a rhythmic  slapping sound. Willie bangs Sue in the Jacuzzi. He is wearing his Santa  hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YES! YES! YES SANTA YES!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two tall water glasses are set down on a sideboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Refill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A splash of orange juice is dolloped into each of the gla and then both are filled to the top with vodka. WIDER on the living room reveals Sue looking around. Her  speech -- and Willie's -- is somewhat impaired:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice place you got. Needs a bit of a  woman's touch, but it's really nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. Just renting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue accepts her refilled glass and sits on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks... So how long will you --  urn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches down to fish under her ass in the sofa cushio and pulls out a red checker. She dully inspects it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How long you gonna be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the holidays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue flips the checker away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the thing, you like kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck no! Whaddya think I'm some kind  of pervert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha? I'm talking about you being  Santa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sways, looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. No, see, the thing is... I'm not  really Santa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blearily she gazes back. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (pause) ...Well -- still -- I gotta thing  for you anyway -- c'mere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans down to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens to reveal Sue on her way out. Willie sways the foyer, a three-quarters-empty bottle of Old Grandad i hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'll see you soon I guess, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm gonna send you some flowers.  Real good expensive ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door. He then tips back the bottle and poli it off with a series of quick gulps. Ever so daintily, he puts the bottle down. A beat later - WHAM! He faints dead away, hitting the floor like a felle tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faintly, distantly, a blood-curdling scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie wakes on the floor to the sound of the scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whuh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks blearily up and immediately grabs his head, feel his hangover. Following his ears he heads toward the hall. He passes  Grandma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger! You're home! Let me fix you  some sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bedroom door crashes open and the Kid emerges screaming and runs right into Willie. He immediately caroms off and goes screaming down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down at his T-shirt. There is a bloody palm-prin on his stomach. He turns the corner to the hall, There is a row of fresh, bloody palm-prints down one side of the hall. The Kid,  screaming, is just disappearing at the far end. Willie follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie enters. The Kid is screaming, jumping up and down and clutching o hand -- the bloody one -- with the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes up and tries to yank the hand, which the hysteric Kid yanks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Lemme look at it. What the fuck  happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Willie drags him to the sink and runs water over the c the Kid takes great gulping breaths and finally manages t say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I cut myself by mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie grabs a vodka bottle standing open on the counter liberally pours some on the hand. The Kid shrieks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot to tell ya, that'll sting.  Okay now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid yanks his hand away and runs off screaming. Willi is left alone in the middle of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He calls after the boy, sincerely trying to help:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Don' t you want me to wrap it in  a T-shirt or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is early morning and the parking lot is empty except f Marcus' van. The Mercedes eventually pulls in, parking be him. Windows roll down. In the driver's seat, Marcus look up from his watch with a scowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: VAN DOORS
dialogues.text: Marcus throws open the back of the van, revealing the  components of the water drill in various prop gift boxes. Willie wears a forbearing smile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids, lemmme tell ya...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head and chuckles as Marcus tosses him an e red Santa sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They'll run ya ragged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse, the security guard unlocks the door and opens up f Willie and Marcus. They enter in costume. Willie lugs the filled sack and seems to be straining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willie) Ho! Ho! Ho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie pants under the weight of his bag:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Willie and Marcus enter the store Gin Slagel drives by their cars, carefully noting their tags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie drops the bag with a loud thud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOD dammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tear your ball again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Together they unload the extremely heavy gifts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do the other thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie follows Marcus behind the Wonderland backdrop. Mar points to an air duct in the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie crouches and Marcus climbs on his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The duct pops open and Marcus climbs in, shimmying down t junction and continuing on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long row of cubicles, each one occupied with Customer  Service Operators. As they work, the loud squeaks and pop metal sounds of a dwarf crawling through a duct are heard above them. Each operator in succession notes the racket, looking up  curiously as the sounds pass overhead. Suddenly, the sounds stop. Everyone returns to work. Then... SQUEAK! POP! SQUEAK! The sounds resume. The operators loo up again as the noises fade away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds continue until Marcus' face appears at the cei duct of an unmanned surveillance room. He focuses on the wall of a hundred identical VCRs and sq to see the brand name: SONY HVR-3200.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lois exits an electronics store with a box slung under he arm, her mouth turned down in pruney disapproval. She pla the box on the hood of her car and we see its printings S HVR-3200. She opens the box, fishes out the remote, then tosses the box and VCR into a nearby trash can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin Slagel walks through the main gate of the heavily  fortified penitentiary, leaving a huge trail of cigarette smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin Slagel sits, smoking and waiting with family members lawyers. A guard enters and motions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright Gin, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin sits down in one of the booths across from a middle-a prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name Roger Merman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing three-to-six for embezzlement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Many accounting questions are not  cut-and-dried --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live at 41 Sage Terrace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly tense) Is it Granma? Is my son alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're fine. Do you have any house  guests?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is bewildered:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...House guests?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks much for your time. God bless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Who are you? WHO ARE YOU?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin sits at his desk sucking in a Pall Mall filterless. B Chipeska sits opposite. Finally Gin exhales like a  crematorium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's fucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopeful) ...Yeah?

dialogues.text: Yeah. Fucked. Frankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a fuckin' whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nothing. I mean, shit, he curses,  yeah. But never around children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No criminal record, no parking tickets  f'Christ's sake, no bad habits, even.  Sex, yeah. But man is a sexual being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' Darwinian. Can't do shit  about that, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. No. Of course not. I'm not  advocating celibacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope not. End of the human fuckin'  race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin turns one palm up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucks large women. What can I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus clears frame, revealing the kid as he walks toward mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser! Dipshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLANG! The kid is hit in the head with a can again. Again no reaction. Someone in the group of frustrated bullies has a fresh id

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wedgie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheering, the six bullies engulf the kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and Willie go about the business of being a Santa- team. Willie sees off another child,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pokemon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus heads to the velvet rope to find the Kid, mussed u and dirty, the band of his underwear around his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santa here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh jeez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus unclips the rope and the Kid approaches Willie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your underwear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the rest? Never mind. What  do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking I wanted a purple  stuffed elephant, not pink, but now  I changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I don't want an elephant at all.  I want a gorilla named Davy for  beating up the skateboard kids who  pull on my underwear and he could  take his orders from the talking  walnut so it wouldn't be my bad thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know when I was your age, I  didn't need no fuckin' gorilla, and  I wasn't any bigger than you. One  day I came crying home to Dad because  four kids had beat me up, and you  know what he did?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He make it all better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He kicked my ass. You know why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went bathroom on Mommy's dishes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He try to teach you not to cry and  be a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, it was because he was a mean,  drunk son of a bitch. When he wasn't  busy busting my ass, he was puttin'  out cigarettes on my neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world's fuckin' unfair -- it  don't give ya nothing. You can wish  all you want but you gotta take what  you need. Stand up for yourself...  stop being such a pussy and kick  those kids in the balls or something. (pause) Or don't, I don't give a shit. Just  leave me the hell out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Kay. Thanks, Santa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, go ahead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps the Kid paternally on the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Get the fuck outta here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Kay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Kid putters away:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happy again) Time for the next lucky boy or girl  to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What gives? Where's the grandson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the rope there, Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus, wary, hesitates but then lets him through. As the walk toward Willie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie is irked by the arrival of an adult:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santa don't do grab-ass, cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Act natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin sits on Willie's knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What the fuck?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are Willie Tugboat Soke and you  are Marcus "The Prince" Skidmore. On  Christmas Eve, you're gonna rob this  store blind. What say we go somewhere  private?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie, Marcus and Gin sit in a booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Research, that's how. I'm a department  store detective Sherlock, that's  what I do. Seven cities in seven  years. Pretty impressive. The stores  change, your names change. You always  get away clean. Yeah, pretty darn  impressive. But let's face facts --  you all are a couple of half-bucket  small-timers. Because of your physical  attributes you've found a niche. I  respect that. But you've also been  caught. By me. So this is the way  how we gonna do things. I don't want  to take over, I don't even want to  change your scam. Whatever you guys  do, it works. All I want is a taste.  When the deed is done, we part ways.  I buy a ranch in Havasu, you take  your little medicine show back on  the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie bolts out of his chair and grabs Gin by the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you listen here, you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus pulls him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy! Easy! Just back off, Willie. I  can handle this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a hard stare Willie settles back into his seat. Mar turns his attention to Gin:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Thirty percent. There's three  of us. Thirty percent. That's fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant thirty-three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half.
